awd_titl_txt: Self-Powered Ultra High Vacuum Technology for Harsh Environment Wireless Sensors
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Objectives and Approaches

The objective of this research is to develop science and technology of radioisotope powered ultra-high vacuum ion-vacuum pumps and ion-gauges, with direct charge radioisotope power sources and wireless transmitters. The approach is to use the electrons emitted from beta-emitting radioisotope thin films to ionize gases, and also generate high voltages for removing gases, while realizing power extraction from the radioisotopes using self-reciprocating cantilever. 

Intellectual Merit:

The effort will lead to building blocks of miniature UHV technology that can be used for a host of micro and nanoscale vacuum devices. The basic processes of beta-particle induced ion creation, secondary and primary ion/electron diffusion within micro vacuum packages will be measured and modeled to optimize atom removal for self-powered pumping. This active getter technology will enable the operation of direct charge radioisotope power sources, which inherently enable very small amounts of radioisotopes to be used to generate useful power levels. 

Broader Impact:

This work will lead to power sources with integrated wireless transmission for decades of operation where life-saving reliability is required. These applications include long-term implants in tiny body cavities, and wireless sensors that need to operate in very high and low temperatures such as car engines, chemical processing centers, and mixed into concrete for structural monitoring. By increasing the reliability of miniature power sources, many applications will become within national and corporate budgets for making lives safer and efficient., A graduate level course will be developed on the science and technology of radioisotopes applied to microsystems.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: 

This research has developed science and technology of ultra-high-vacuum technology for very small, yet powerful wireless sensor nodes with integrated RF-transmitter. The effort initially that uses miniscule and safe amounts of radioactivity to provide operation as long as 100 years. Self-powered Sputter Ion Pumps, vacuum gauges, and micro-scale alkali metal getter packages will be developed for enabling zero-external-power UHV packages. In addition to the use of radioisotope materials the research explored the use of pyroelectric properties of crystals to generate very high voltages generated by resistively heating the crystals. Due to many practical limitations and issues with the license to use radioisotope materials Lithium-niobate crystals were used to generate 1-10kV voltages using a 1-volt power supply. The high electric field ionizes gas molecules creating electrons and ions. The electric field due to the voltage also accelerates the ions and electrons such that they gain sufficient momentum to impact with sufficient kinetic energy to penetrate the electrodes, hence pumping away the gas molecules. The work has led to such pumps and can be used for implementing noble gases such as helium, which are very hard to stop diffusing through packaging. The lithium niobate ionizers have also been used to generate ion pulses in air such that pulses of ions can be guided and measured across electrodes. This setup of the method enables the use of the method to develop a portable ion-mobility based gas sensors.

Broader Impact:

The effort has led to an invention of a new ion pump that can be implemented using a low voltage power supply, even a battery, to heat and generate thousands of volts using atomic scale phenomenon of pyroelectricity. This result can translate to a whole host of portable instruments that require miniature high vacuum pumps, that are battery powered, and energy and power efficient. The material in this class has led to two papers, and multiple other proposals and ideas where high voltages are required to be generated in small working spaces. The research has allowed the PI to teach the material in freshman classes on the challenges of miniaturizing vacuum instrumentation, and how microsystems research using MEMS and novel materials. The research on radioisotope powered high voltage and ionization generation has been presented in numerous invited papers. This research ash funded the research of one graduate student who is now working at Intel corporation, and also the undergraduate research of two undergraduate students.
